chunks.en: Feels like the interaction latency of macOS is very poor.

chunks.en:
I use macOS for work during the day, and Windows at home in the evenings for gaming and browsing forums.
I always feel like the Mac is a beat slower, a sluggish feeling. Typing never feels smooth, especially when writing documents~

Today, out of boredom, I specifically compared the input latency of the two systems.
Mac: M2Pro 32g system 15.3.1, Win: Win11, 13600kf
Restarted, and randomly typed in the Chrome tab bar, pressing directly with all fingers on the keyboard.
Divided into situations with Chinese input and pure English.
Win: Needless to say, absolute instant typing, can't feel any delay at all.
The result on Mac, in two situations:
1. abc English input mode, almost no delay, at least I can't feel it.
But if compared, Win is definitely faster.
2. Chinese input mode, I use WeChat input, can physically feel the delay, about 200ms after my fingers leave the keyboard, the screen responds completely.
Not to mention that the Mac also has the problem of the input method becoming more and more laggy after being turned on for a long time.
Especially when too many Chrome windows are open, the memory turns yellow uses swap space, the input delay is so bad that it can affect the rhythm of typing.
The Mac's delay problem is also reflected in many system applications, such as the settings page, quickly switching options with the mouse.
Activity Monitor page, quickly clicking processes back and forth with the mouse can freeze itself.
Initially clicking into this technical discussion thread, I expected to see experts share Mac system optimization experience.

chunks.en: As a result, I saw another annoying opposing and inflammatory reply educating the green avatar user on the 32nd floor. You can see him in most posts that compare Windows and Mac, attacking Microsoft products and collectively attacking and mocking Microsoft users like he's avenging his father's murder for ten years, but he never outputs useful viewpoints, only uses rhetorical questions to create opposition and pollute content in the forum.
Fortunately, there are more and more Mac bugs now, and his remarks are becoming more and more like a clown's, he can only use 'fanboy' as a catchphrase.

chunks.en: In the days when Mac was better than Windows, this user was so powerful acting like a tiger with the help of a fox ğŸ¤­ I wonder if he will call Mac users like me 'Mac fanboys' too?
Conclusion: The macOS version of WeChat input method is very bad.
Although I agree that the quality of macOS has seriously declined now, it's probably not as bad as you describe. I suggest controlling variables to investigate.

chunks.zh: macOS æœ¬æ¥å°±å¾ˆå¡ï¼ŒWindows10 åŸºæœ¬éƒ½æ˜¯æŒ‡å“ªæ‰“å“ªï¼Œè½¯ä»¶ç§’å¼€ï¼ŒWin11 å¼€äº† WD å’Œ VBS ä¼šå¡ä¸å°‘ï¼Œå…³äº†ä¹Ÿèƒ½å‡ ä¹å®Œå…¨æ¢å¤ï¼Œä½† macOS æ˜¯å…³äº† gatekeeper å’Œ SIP åä¹Ÿæ¢å¤ä¸å¤š
chunks.en: macOS is inherently laggy. Windows 10 is basically point-and-click, software opens instantly. Win11 with WD and VBS enabled is noticeably laggy, but turning them off can almost completely restore performance, but macOS doesn't recover much even after turning off gatekeeper and SIP.
I think these are okay, but the biggest impact on efficiency is that macOS animations can't be turned off. Some operations have become muscle memory, and animations feel very annoying...

The longer macOS runs, the more bugs there are. I now find that there is also a delay in mouse wheel scrolling, and restarting can eliminate the delay, but it appears after booting for more than a week.
Windows never has this problem.

chunks.en: Your feeling is right, macOS is far more laggy than Windows. My eight-year-old Intel CPU running Windows is smoother than the m3 Pro chip. Actually, the reason is simple, how many users does macOS have, how many users does Windows have, Microsoft's optimization over the years has not been in vain.

chunks.en: Now the speed of wayland on Linux is faster than Windows.
Windows has slowed down a bit here in Windows 11.
However, macOS is indeed slow.
Without Windows as a comparison, I'm not sure about the speed.
Also using WeChat input method, there is occasional delay when switching between input in different apps and direct English input with the first letter.
Feels like it's 15.3.1's fault.
After I updated, the Chinese input method has a probability of automatically clearing the entered Pinyin during typing.
Why not use the built-in input method to test?

chunks.zh: æˆ‘è§‰å¾— win11 å¾ˆçƒ‚ï¼Œ14 ä»£ i5 å’Œ 4060 ï¼Œçª—å£æœ€å°åŒ–åŠ¨ç”»éƒ½ä¸æµç•…ï¼Œæ€»ä¼šå¡ä¸€ä¸‹ï¼ŒMac å°±å¾ˆæµç•…
chunks.en: I think Win11 is terrible, 14th generation i5 and 4060, even the window minimize animation isn't smooth, it always lags a bit, Mac is very smooth.
Linux and macOS applications take a while to open for the first time, even very small applications are not quick.
Simple Windows applications open instantly.
Never use third-party input methods, it's basic common sense for information security.
@Nosub On the contrary, I think Windows is extremely laggy, macOS is still smoother.
Input method bug, restarting can solve it, you're lucky it's just lag, severe cases will show the spinning beachball, who knows what the input method is doing during that time.
In my personal experience, Win is far inferior to Mac, of course, this is just a personal opinion, ğŸ‘Œ

chunks.en: Both Windows and Mac are used with English interfaces. I don't install domestic software unless necessary/I don't install extra software if the built-in system can meet my needs/I only use the built-in input method/I purchase paid software according to my needs and don't use any cracked versions. Windows is a third-generation Xeon Platinum 8375C+512GB@24H2 RAM+4090FE. The Mac mini is a [emailÂ protected]M1 single core, which of course kills the 8375C, but many Mac software open much slower than Windows for the first time/I haven't encountered input lag/I have encountered peripheral failures on both, and restarting solves the problem (I haven't encountered either in the last 2 years, it used to be a Logi Options issue)/Long-term non-shutdown stability Mac is significantly stronger than Windows (my Mac mini has not been reinstalled since I bought it at the end of 2020, and has been OTA upgraded to the current 15.3.1) Windows has needed to be reinstalled every 6-9 months in the past few years (1-2 times because of Windows update failures).

chunks.zh: @ACSOUV è¿™äº‹å§ï¼Œå¾ˆç®€å•ï¼Œä½ å¼€ä¸ª vm è™šæ‹Ÿæœºï¼Œç”¨åŒæ ·çš„é…ç½®ï¼Œå®‰è£… Windows ï¼ŒMacOS ï¼Œå’Œ Linux ï¼Œçœ‹çœ‹è°å¡é¡¿å°±çŸ¥é“äº†ï¼Œå› ä¸ºæˆ‘æœ€è¿‘ä¸€ç›´åœ¨åšè·¨å¹³å°çš„å¼€å‘ï¼Œè™šæ‹Ÿæœºé‡Œé¢çš„ MacOS åŸºæœ¬å¡çš„ä¸è¡Œï¼Œç›´ç™½ç‚¹å°±æ˜¯ Windows å’Œ Linux å¤šä½çš„é…ç½®éƒ½å¯ä»¥ç”¨ï¼ŒMacOS åŸºæœ¬ç”¨ä¸äº†ï¼Œè¿™æœ¬èº«å°±è¯´æ˜äº†é—®é¢˜ã€‚
chunks.en: @ACSOUV It's simple, open a VM virtual machine, use the same configuration, install Windows, macOS, and Linux, and see which one is laggy. Because I have been doing cross-platform development recently, the MacOS in the virtual machine is basically extremely laggy, to put it bluntly, Windows and Linux can be used on very low configurations, MacOS is basically unusable, which in itself explains the problem.

The "Settings" of macOS are outrageous. First, to open it, you have to go through a round of icon jumping. After the interface pops up, click on any item on the left sidebar, and the page on the right takes seconds to switch.
The speed of Windows 11's settings is actually worse than before. If you bring out the old version of the Win control panel, none of these systems can compete.

@SeaTac I also only use the built-in input method, but the biggest problem with the Mac's built-in input method is not the delay. Even if the delay is low, it is useless. The accuracy rate of input candidate words is too low, which is far from the built-in input method of Win.
